content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic sarcomatoid carcinoma of prostate with widespread metastatic disease
	Initial diagnosis March 2023 - T3bN0M1 with lung, liver, and brain metastases
	PSA 0.1, HR-deficiency positive on molecular testing
?
I reviewed [redacted name] today in the complex care clinic following his recent admission for seizures and deteriorating mobility. Unfortunately, imaging confirms significant disease progression across multiple sites despite third-line therapy.
?
He was initially diagnosed in March 2023 with an unusual sarcomatoid variant of prostate cancer, presenting with widespread metastatic disease. First-line docetaxel was discontinued after 3 cycles due to neutropenic sepsis. Second-line enzalutamide was stopped in December 2023 due to radiological progression. Third-line carboplatin/cabazitaxel was commenced in January 2024 but has been poorly tolerated with grade 3 fatigue and peripheral neuropathy.
?
Recent MRI brain (April 15th 2024) shows enlargement of known cerebral metastases with new lesions and significant surrounding edema, explaining his recent seizures. CT chest/abdomen/pelvis demonstrates progressive disease in lung and liver with new bone metastases. His PSA remains low at 0.1 reflecting the poorly differentiated nature of his disease.
?
He has deteriorated significantly over the past month, now requiring wheelchair assistance and spending most of the day in bed (PS 3). He reports worsening headaches despite increased dexamethasone, ongoing right-sided weakness, and increasing breathlessness. His wife reports he is becoming increasingly confused.
?
Given his poor performance status and clear evidence of progressive disease despite three lines of therapy, I have had a detailed discussion with [redacted name] and his wife about focusing on symptom control. They understand and accept that further systemic anti-cancer therapy would carry significant risks with little chance of benefit.
?
I have referred him to our palliative care team for urgent review and increased his dexamethasone to 8mg twice daily. I have arranged urgent whole brain radiotherapy (20Gy in 5 fractions) starting tomorrow to help with his neurological symptoms. The acute oncology team will monitor him during radiotherapy, and I will review him next week with the palliative care team.
